title: Covid Retrospective
content:
These things happened during covid... interesting, no?

BY JANE ROBERTS AND ALEXANDER KENNEDY
03.17.2021

Nearly two and a half years since a mysterious cluster of pneumonia cases were first reported in Wuhan, China, SARS-CoV-2 has killed more than 6 million people and sickened hundreds of millions more around the world. In that time, many governments — from the local to national level — have gone to extraordinary lengths to combat the spread of the deadly pathogen, from closing borders and implementing contact tracing systems to adopting mask mandates and shutting down businesses. Others — including at times the United States — have downplayed the severity of the virus and touted unproven treatments against it.

As health care workers burned out, the development of vaccines brought new hope. But even with billions of shots now in arms, much of the world’s population has yet to receive a single dose. While many people living in low-income countries simply still lack access, pockets of Americans and others have chosen to willfully forgo the vaccine — and push back on efforts to mandate it. Following the rise of Delta, the Omicron variant swept the globe, its sheer numbers inundating hospitals.

While cases declined in many parts of the globe following records in January of this year, a new Omicron subvariant led to new spikes, including in Hong Kong and the U.K. With the pandemic now in its third year, scientists are scrambling to determine where things are headed next. But what may already be clear, many experts say, is that the coronavirus is likely to become endemic — meaning rather than disappearing, it will become less disruptive as the population builds immunity over time. In the meantime, here’s a look back at how the pandemic has played out in the U.S. so far.

Note: This timeline will be periodically updated as new developments occur.

headline: First U.S. Case
content: On Jan. 21, 2020, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed the United States' first case of the novel coronavirus, in a man in Washington state. The man reported recently traveling to Wuhan, China, where the virus was first discovered and had been rapidly spreading. He arrived back in the U.S. on Jan. 15, just a couple of days before three major airports began screening passengers for the virus.

headline: Public Health Emergency
content: U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services Alex Azar declared the coronavirus a public health emergency on Jan. 31, just one day after the World Health Organization did the same. President Donald J. Trump issued a proclamation barring foreign nationals — excluding immediate family members of U.S. citizens and permanent residents — from entering the country if they had visited China in the previous two weeks.

headline: Whistleblowing Doctor Dies
content: Dr. Li Wenliang, a Chinese ophthalmologist who tried to warn others about the developing outbreak in Wuhan, died after contracting the virus. In December, Li sounded an alarm to fellow doctors in a chat room, but was accused of making false statements and quickly silenced by authorities. Mourners across the U.S., and the world, paid their respects.

headline: Cruise Ship Quarantine
content: Following an outbreak on a cruise ship docked at a Japanese port, hundreds of American passengers were evacuated and flown to California and Texas. At least 14 evacuees tested positive for the coronavirus — which the World Health Organization dubbed Covid-19 — and all were subject to a two-week quarantine upon their return to the U.S.

headline: Nursing Home Outbreak
content: Covid-19 spread among staff and residents at a nursing home in Kirkland, Washington. The facility would go on to be linked to dozens of deaths and face a $611,000 fine for deficiencies that lead to the country’s first major coronavirus outbreak. With many older residents living in close quarters, nursing homes are particularly vulnerable to the virus.

headline: Pandemic Declaration
content: The World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a pandemic, as global cases rose above 118,000 and deaths topped 4,000. In a media briefing, WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus advised countries that with measures to “test, treat, isolate, trace, and mobilize their people in the response,” it’s would still be possible to “change the course of this pandemic.”

headline: Stay at Home
content: California became the first state to issue a stay-at-home order for residents, directing them to leave only for exercise and other essential purposes. Many other states would soon follow, with officials banning indoor dining and prohibiting large gatherings, among other measures. Many companies shut down their offices and asked employees to work from home until further notice.
A highway sign in Los Angeles advised residents to stay home to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Visual: Aydin Palabiyikoglu/Getty

headline: The Rise of Face Masks
content: After weeks of discouraging the use of masks among the general public — in part to ensure supplies remained available to medical professionals — U.S. health officials began encouraging Americans to wear cloth face coverings to help stop the spread of Covid-19. Instructions for fashioning homemade masks proliferated online, and community members came together to sew masks for those in need.

headline: Mobile Morgues
content: On April 7, New York City experienced its deadliest day of the Covid-19 pandemic so far; more than 800 residents passed away. With morgues and funeral homes overwhelmed, bodies were stored in refrigerated trucks provided by the Federal Emergency Management Agency or FEMA.

At Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island, members of New York City chapter of the Laborer's Union International, Local 79, built shelving for trailers that would hold the bodies of Covid-19 victims. Visual: Pacific Press/Getty

headline: Beginnings in California
content: Post-mortem testing of two people who died in Santa Clara County in February suggested that the coronavirus was circulating in California at least a month earlier than originally thought. According to the county medical examiner, a 57-year-old woman who died on Feb. 6 was the first known person to die from Covid-19 in the U.S., followed by a 69-year-old man, who died on Feb. 17.

A respiratory specialist looked through the glass as a team at Boston Medical Center performed a tracheostomy on a Cocivd-19 patient on the intensive care unit floor of the hospital. Visual: Erin Clark/The Boston Globe via Getty Images

headline: Spike in Illinois
content: Illinois recorded its largest single-day Covid-19 spike, with 4,014 new cases recorded. The increase coincided with the state’s increase in testing. “We have not had [a number] in the 4,000 range before,” Ngozi Ezike, head of the Illinois Department of Public Health, told Block Club Chicago, “but we also have never had tests in the 29,000 range.” As deaths rose and thousands were hospitalized, Gov. J.B. Pritzker asked residents to continue following the state’s stay-at-home order.
People spread out across social-distancing circles at Dolores Park in San Francisco. Jane Tyska/Digital First Media/East Bay Times via Getty Images

headline: U.S. Record
content: The U.S. became the first country in the world to surpass 100,000 deaths from Covid-19. Demographic analyses laid bare the racial disparities of that toll. In Alabama, while only 27 percent of residents are Black, they accounted for 44 percent of Covid-19 deaths. In Michigan, African Americans make up 14 percent of the population but made up 40 percent of deaths in the state.

A couple exchanged vows as part of a virtual wedding ceremony in Morris Plains, New Jersey. Such ceremonies grew in popularity as in-person weddings were cancelled or drastically downsized due to the pandemic. Visual: Theo Wargo/Getty Images

headline: Covid Lung Transplant
content: A Chicago woman in her 20s became the first known person in the U.S. to receive a double lung transplant for Covid-19. The woman, who was otherwise healthy, developed a severe case of the disease and spent two months in an intensive care unit. Her lungs were so damaged that doctors said a transplant was her only chance at survival.

headline: California Mask Mandate
content: California Gov. Gavin Newsom issued a statewide mask mandate. With coronavirus cases increasing, the Department of Public Health said, the order required people to wear face coverings in public spaces to “limit the release of infected droplets when talking, coughing, and/or sneezing, as well as reinforce physical distancing."
A young girl walked with her mother on Santee Alley in the Garment District in Downtown L.A., where masks were required for shopping. Visual: Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times via Getty Images

headline: Aerosol Spread
content: The WHO revised its guidance on Covid-19 transmission, acknowledging that it’s possible the virus could be airborne in indoor spaces. The update came after hundreds of scientists around the world urged the agency to reevaluate its stance. While the WHO maintained that transmission occured primarily through close contact with infected people, other experts argued that tiny droplets called aerosols might be behind superspreader events.

headline: Florida Takes the Lead
content: On July 23, Florida had the worst Covid-19 outbreak in the country, with more than 10,000 new cases announced in a single day. The state reported that out of the 3.2 million tests administered it had administered so far, 12.1 percent had come back positive — well above the WHO recommendation of 5 percent. Despite the spike, Disney World reopened after being shut down for four months.

Jackson Pijanowski 9, (L) and Bright Owens, (R), supporters calling for Hillsborough County schools to reopen, protested ahead of a meeting of the school board at the Hillsborough County Public Schools district office on Aug. 6, 2020 in Tampa, Florida. Visual: Octavio Jones/Getty Images

headline: Covid in Kids
content: As Texas parents considered sending their children back to school in the fall, Covid-19 testing slowed and, of the tests that were being administered, around one-fifth were coming back positive. While evidence suggested that children were less likely to experience severe illness than adults, they can and do spread the virus.

headline: College Outbreak
content: More than 1,200 students and 166 employees tested positive for Covid-19 at the University of Alabama after the school reopened for in-person instruction earlier in the month. Other institutions, including the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and Michigan State, also experienced outbreaks, with both schools shifting to remote learning.

headline: AstraZeneca Concerns
content: AstraZeneca paused a large study on its Covid-19 vaccine after a patient in the United Kingdom experienced a suspected serious adverse reaction. A spokesperson told STAT that the company initiated the hold on the Phase 3 trial, which was being conducted at sites across the U.S., “to allow review of safety data.”

headline: School Covid Dashboard
content: Texas launched an online dashboard to track coronavirus cases in public schools. As of Sept. 17, the dashboard showed 4,519 positive cases, divided fairly equally between students and staff. In addition to reporting cases to the state, schools were still required to notify local health authorities.

headline: Trump Tests Positive
content: President Donald J. Trump and First Lady Melania Trump tested positive for Covid-19. On Sept. 26, the president held an event at the White House Rose Garden to announce Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s appointment to the Supreme Court. Several attendees also tested positive, as did many of Trump’s other close contacts.
President Trump exited the White House to head to a rally in Pennsylvania after recovering from Covid-19 earlier in the month. Visual: Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images

headline: Voting in a Pandemic
content: As the Nov. 3 presidential election approached, STAT reported that public health officials were weighing in on how to stay safe while voting in a pandemic. For those who hadn't already submitted their votes by mail or local dropbox, health authorities said common sense precautions like mask wearing, social distancing, and sanitizing pens between voters should help.

headline: Illinois Cases Surge
content: On Nov. 16 and Nov. 17, Illinois recorded its highest average daily case toll since the start of the pandemic. On those days, the state averaged almost 12,400 new cases a day, the 12th day in a row with more than 10,000 new cases tallied. Gov. J.B. Pritzker announced new restrictions to combat the spread.

Ignoring CDC guidance not to travel for the Thanksgiving holiday to prevent the spread of the virus, travelers waited in line a TSA checkpoint at Orlando International Airport. Visual: Paul Hennessy/NurPhoto via Getty Images

headline: First Vaccine Authorized
content: On Dec. 11, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration granted an emergency use authorization for the first vaccine against Covid-19. The shot, developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, would first be made available to nursing home residents and health care workers. Pfizer was set to supply 100 million doses to the U.S. government by March.

headline: Moderna Quickly Follows
content: The FDA issued an emergency use authorization for a second vaccine, approving the federal government’s plan to distribute some 5.9 million doses of Moderna’s vaccine the following week. “We likely will see shots in the arm by the very early part of next week, I would hope Monday or Tuesday,” Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, told the Today on Dec. 18.

headline: Deadly December
content: California experienced its deadliest month yet in the pandemic, reporting more than 5,300 deaths related to the virus in December so far. The state's previous record came in August with some 3,800 fatalities. While the number of new cases was beginning to stabilize, the state still faced surges in deaths and hospitalizations, as well as limited or no availability in its ICUs.
A health care worker exits the Covid-19 intensive care unit on New Year's Day at the United Memorial Medical Center in Houston, Texas. Visual: Go Nakamura/Getty Images

headline: Texas Hospitalizations Spike
content: Texas reported more than 14,000 Covid-19 hospitalizations today, its highest number since the pandemic began. According to the state’s health department, Thanksgiving and Christmas get togethers helped to drive the rise in cases. Due to the influx of patients, the availability of intensive care unit beds is extremely limited.

headline: New Variants Identified
content: Researchers identified two new variants of the coronavirus in Columbus, Ohio. Their findings, which had not yet been peer reviewed at this time, suggested that at least one of the variants contained the same mutation found in variants from the U.K. and South Africa. Scientists say the emergence of variants isn’t itself a cause for concern. What’s important is whether they turn out to be more contagious or lead to more severe disease.
People waited outside a Covid-19 vaccine distribution center at the Kedren Community Health Center in L.A. Visual: Mario Tama/Getty Images

headline: U.K. Variant Warning
content: Public health officials warned Americans that the coronavirus variant first identified in the United Kingdom could become the dominant strain in the U.S. in the coming months — leading to a spike in cases. While it was not yet clear if the variant would cause more deaths or severe disease, the CDC urged people to remain vigilant in their pandemic precautions.

headline: J&J Jab Authorized
content: The FDA greenlit the single dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine under an emergency use authorization. With three options now available, more Americans would be able to get their Covid-19 shots. But because Johnson & Johnson had a lower efficacy than Pfizer and Moderna, public health officials worried that some people could be reluctant to get it.

headline: Spikes Across Country
content: Although millions of people were getting vaccinated every day, and caseloads were down across the United States, counts in some pockets of the country rose once again. According to The Washington Post, Michigan’s daily number of infections recently increased, as did tallies in Minnesota and Maryland.

headline: One Year In
content: Just over a year into the pandemic, the CDC released data showing that Covid-19 was the third-leading cause of death in the U.S. in 2020. Of the approximately 375,000 deaths attributed to the disease caused by the virus, people of color were hit the hardest.

headline: Colleges Split on Vaccines
content: Some U.S. colleges said they would require students to get vaccinated before returning to campus in the fall, while others would leave the decision up to individuals. Some schools, including Virginia Tech, did not believe they could legally mandate vaccines that had only received emergency use authorization from the FDA. But legal scholars suggested the larger issue would come from states pushing back on such requirements.

headline: Mask Guidelines Eased
content: The CDC eased mask guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals. Those who had received a two-dose regimen of the Pfizer or Moderna shots, or a single dose of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, could forgo masks when doing outdoor activities or meeting with friends for outdoor dining. The agency still recommended masking indoors, regardless of vaccination status.

headline: One Step Further
content: The agency relaxed its guidelines further today, giving fully vaccinated individuals the go ahead to ditch their masks and forgo social distancing indoors. While masks will still be required on planes and public transportation, in updating the guidance, the CDC cited three studies supporting the efficacy of the vaccines.

headline: CDC on Breakthrough Cases
content: Following widely publicized reports of Covid-19 infection in fully vaccinated people, a new CDC report suggested that such breakthrough cases were extremely rare. Of the 101 million U.S. adults who had been fully vaccinated by the end of April, the report said, just .01 percent — or about 10,260 — got Covid-19.

People took to the beach in Coney Island to enjoy some fresh air after months of Covid-19 restrictions. By this point, nearly 60 percent of adult New Yorkers had been fully vaccinated against the virus. Visual: Mathias Wasik/picture alliance via Getty Images

headline: Deaths Top 600,000
content: By mid-June 2021, more than 600,000 people had died from Covid-19 in the United States, more than any other country thus far. Still, public health experts pointed out, the numbers had ticked up much more slowly since vaccines became available.

headline: Crisis of Unvaccinated
content: According to reporting from The Associated Press, most of the people dying from Covid-19 in the U.S. at this point were unvaccinated. Of the more than 18,000 people who died of the illness in May 2021, only 150, or less than 1 percent, were fully vaccinated. More than a third of those eligible still had yet to receive their first dose of a Covid vaccine.

headline: Missouri Surge
content: Covid-19 cases rose rapidly in Missouri, increasing 46 percent during the previous two weeks. According to ABC News, the CDC assigned two members of its federal "surge team" to the state — an epidemiologist to work on "genetic sequencing and data analysis, and an adviser who's working with local officials on how to address vaccine hesitancy."

Tens of thousands of fans gathered outside of Fiserv Forum to celebrate the Milwaukee Bucks 2021 NBA Championship win. With much of Wisconsin's population still unvaccinated at this point, health experts said they expected to see new Covid cases tied to the event. Visual: Jamie Sabau/Getty Images

headline: The Show Goes On
content: An estimated 100,000 people gathered at Chicago’s Grant Park on July 29 for the kickoff of the city’s Lollapalooza music festival. For some, the event — which required attendees to show their vaccination card or a recent negative Covid test — signaled optimism about the return of live events. But others cautioned that as the delta variant spread, many attendees could contract Covid.

headline: Breakthrough Transmission
content: In August, CDC director Rochelle Walensky announced that people who get Covid-19 even after being fully vaccinated could still transmit the virus to others. The revelation prompted the public health agency to revise its guidance once again, recommending that fully vaccinated people continue to wear masks indoors. "Our vaccines are working exceptionally well," Walensky told CNN. "They continue to work well for delta, with regard to severe illness and death — they prevent it. But what they can't do anymore is prevent transmission."

headline: Struggles in the South
content: States across the southern U.S. are experiencing another surge in Covid-19 cases. In Mississippi, NPR reported, health officials warned that "the state's hospital system could collapse in five to 10 days if the current trajectory continues." Meanwhile, Arkansas experienced record hospitalizations and 90 percent of ICU beds in Florida were full.

headline: Booster Shots Coming Soon
content: As U.S. public health officials warned of potentially waning immunity against the coronavirus in the coming months, booster shots of both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines were set to become available to American adults in September. While people who received the single dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine would also likely need an additional shot, research was still ongoing.

A boy rode a bicycle past a sign at Pershing School in Orlando advising that face masks are required for students through Oct. 30, 2021. On Aug. 27, a Florida judge threw out Gov. Ron DeSantis' ban on face mask mandates in schools. Visual: Paul Hennessy/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images

headline: Federal Vaccine Mandates
content: On Sept. 9, President Biden announced that all federal workers and contractors would be required to get vaccinated against Covid-19. In addition, companies with 100 employees or more would have to ensure workers were vaccinated or have them undergo weekly testing. "The bottom line — we're going to protect vaccinated workers from unvaccinated coworkers," Biden said.

headline: Rules Relax in Florida
content: Florida's new surgeon general, Dr. Joseph Ladapo, issued an executive order to make quarantine optional for students exposed to Covid-19. While Gov. Ron DeSantis stated that the order was aimed at preventing healthy students from unnecessarily missing school, many public health officials warned that it could fuel asymptomatic transmission.

headline: 700,000 Covid-19 Deaths
content: The U.S. hit a grim pandemic milestone on Oct. 1, as the nation's Covid-19 death toll surpassed 700,000. While vaccines were now available to all Americans 12 and older, tens of millions held out, allowing the more contagious delta variant to spread.

In Douglas County, Nebraska — the state's most populous — the health department reported 190 new Covid-19 cases on Oct. 8. That brings the county total to more than 84,500 cases since the pandemic began. On Oct. 7, the health department said 89 percent of hospital beds were taken and ICUs were 87 percent full.

headline: Colin Powell Dies From Covid
content: Former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell died after a battle with Covid-19. Powell, who held the post under President George W. Bush, was fully vaccinated but had a compromised immune system due to treatment he was receiving for blood cancer.

headline: Pfizer Authorized for Kids
content: On Nov. 2, the CDC recommended Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 5 to 11, expanding eligibility to tens of millions of Americans. While many parents welcomed the news, others — including those who are vaccinated themselves — expressed hesitation about consenting for their kids.
Thousands took to the California State Capitol steps in Sacramento to protest the Covid-19 vaccine mandate for students. Visual: Anibal Martel/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images

headline: Alarm Over Omicron Variant
content: The WHO warned that the omicron variant, which first appeared in South Africa earlier in November, was very likely to spread globally. “Given mutations that may confer immune escape potential and possibly transmissibility advantage, the likelihood of potential further spread of omicron at the global level is high,” the agency said in a technical brief. Though data was limited at this time, symptoms with the new variant were reported to be fairly mild.

headline: Covid-19 Holiday Surge
content: With Christmas and New Year's fast approaching, cases of Covid-19 surged in New York City. In a tweet, Dr. Jay Varma, a health adviser to Mayor Bill de Blasio, wrote that from Dec. 9 to Dec. 12, the city's test positivity rate went from 3.9 percent to 7.8 percent. With a reporting lag of a few days, however, the true rate could have actually been higher.

headline: Virus Grounds Flights
content: Covid-19 upended holiday plans once again, as staffing issues caused hundreds of flight cancellations on Christmas Day. Delta, United, and Alaska, among other airlines, said employees infected with and exposed to the omicron variant left them without the staffing necessary to operate.

headline: Single Day Case Record
content: On Jan. 10, the U.S. recorded 1.35 million new Covid-19 infections, the largest single-day total of any country in the world since the start of the pandemic. The record was accompanied by the highest number of patients hospitalized with Covid-19, reaching more than 136,000.

headline: U.S. Drops Vaccine Rule
content: The U.S. Department of Labor dropped a vaccine mandate for businesses with more than 100 employers, after it was blocked by the Supreme Court. The rule had been aimed at increasing vaccine update, but faced strong pushback from conservative groups.

headline: Vaccine for Kids Delayed
content: The FDA has delayed a decision over whether to authorize the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for the nation’s youngest children for at least another two months. While the agency had originally planned to make a call by the following week, Pfizer and BioNTech submitted new data that will require additional review. While parents await the authorization, the agency noted the best way to protect kids is to continue following masking and social distancing guidelines

headline: Masks Come Off
content: In new guidelines, the CDC advised that many Americans can once again forgo masks and social distancing. To assess a community’s risk, the recommendations direct counties to look at a handful of factors, including new Covid-19 cases per 100,000 people and hospital admissions. The agency suggests a tiered approach to masking based on local conditions and individual’s personal health risks.

headline: Living with Covid
content: As the second anniversary of the Covid-19 pandemic approached this week, public health experts weighed in on a path to the “next normal.” In a 136-page report, the authors — who included Paul Offit, director of the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia’s Vaccine Education Center, and Jill Jim, executive director of the Navajo Department of Health — suggested the U.S. shift its Covid-19 response to include other respiratory viruses, improve indoor air quality, among other initiatives.

headline: A Fresh Warning
content: Although Covid-19 cases have declined dramatically since record spikes in January, top White House coronavirus adviser Anthony Fauci warned Americans to remain vigilant. In the U.K., where restrictions are being lifted and protection from vaccines is waning, cases rose again due to an Omicron subvariant called BA.2. With the U.S. often following a similar pattern to the U.K., Fauci said new funding for additional vaccine doses and therapeutic treatments is sorely need.

headline: County Level Risks
content: New reported cases were trending downward in Kentucky, but nearly a dozen counties were still catergorized as high by the CDC, meaning residents were advised to mask indoors while in public and take additional precautions if they were at an elevated risk for severe disease, among other measures.

headline: Detecting the Next Surge
content: Health experts have warned that as testing decreases, the U.S. could face difficulties in detecting the next wave of Covid-19. Restrictions have loosened across the country, and many Americans are eager to leave the pandemic behind. But as Gregg Gonsalves, an infectious disease expert at Yale, told Bloomberg, the " late waves of the pandemics are sometimes the deadliest because people have given up.”
